newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia to press Japan over rice deferral.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia to press Japan over rice deferral.

text.p: A decision by Japan to defer its next round of rice imports until November would severely disadvantage Australia and prompt official representations in Tokyo, a spokesman for the Ricegrowers Cooperative Ltd said.

Chris Black was was commenting on a Reuters report from Tokyo that Japan was likely to defer its next round of rice imports until November because of a bumper domestic harvest and sluggish sales of foreign rice,

"Any tender after the beginning of September relegates Australia to second position because northern hemisphere suppliers -- the rest of the potential suppliers -- have their new harvest coming in," Black said.
With Australia the world's only counter-seasonal rice producer, northern hemisphere producers include all other rice suppliers in the world, including Japan, he said.
"Australia is then in a position of being disadvantaged against those suppliers," he said.
Australia understood Japan's problems with domestic rice availability, he said.
"But there are very good reasons from the point of view of the Japanese consumer (to have the) opportunity to have a very high quality product at a time when no one else has it," he said.
This was a point which Australia had been promoting in Japan, both through the trade and through trade representatives, he said.
Australia would be seeking to clarify the latest tender position with Japanese officials in Tokyo, he said.
If the tender schedule followed last year, there would be progressive tenders from the end of July. Earlier tenders were to the advantage of Australia, he said.
"We are maintaining pressure to attempt to have the tendering process initiated as early as possible in the year and we'll continue with that message," he said.
Continuing controversy over Japan's rice imports imports follows a 1993 GATT deal under which Japan agreed to gradually open its rice market to import 511,000 tonnes a year.
Japan's Food Agency said Japan had so far bought 39,500 tonnes of this year's quota, mainly from China and Australia.
Black said Australia had won exports of 833 tonnes to Japan from the July 26 tender through the sale of 170 tonnes of high-quality koshihikari and 612 tonnes of japonica rice.
This shipment would have arrived in Japan in the past couple of days, he said.

The Japanese rice market was worth "tens of millions of dollars" in overall trade, although extreme variability in annual trade made it impossible to put an accurate yearly figure on the trade, Black said.
Short-term projected availability of Australian rice for Japan was about 200,000 tonnes a year by year 2000, or about one-quarter of the market, he said.
